G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 26 (district court c.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in Newton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 26 (district court civil jurisdiction) and the general venue provisions because the acts and omissions alleged occurred in Newton and the Defendant resides or may be found in Middlesex County.

Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. (1 Cush.) 292.proposition: The elements of an action in negligence under Massachusetts law are: (a) the existence of a duty of care owed by the Defendant to the Plaintiff; (b) a breach of that duty by the Defendant; and (c) actual and proximate causation of damages to the Plaintiff resulting from the breach. See Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. (1 Cush.) 292 (1850); see also Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 281–285 (general principles of negligence).
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. (1 Cush.) 292.support_reasoning: Brown v. Kendall is a foundational Massachusetts negligence case, but it does not set out the modern, element-based formulation of negligence as duty, breach, and actual/proximate causation. Instead, it focuses on whether an unintentional injury occurring during a lawful act is actionable only upon proof of fault (lack of due care) and on who bears the burden of proving negligence. The opinion discusses due care, lawful acts, and contributory negligence, but it does not articulate the three-element structure or the causation concepts in the way the proposition states, so it does not directly support that specific elements test, though it is historically related to negligence doctrine.
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. (1 Cush.) 292.relevant_excerpt: “If the act of hitting the plaintiff was unintentional, on the part of the defendant, and done in the doing of a lawful act, then the defendant was not liable, unless it was done in the want of exercise of due care, adapted to the exigency of the case, and therefore such want of due care became part of the plaintiff's case, and the burden of proof was on the plaintiff to establish it. … [W]hen the proof is all in … unless it also appears … that the defendant is chargeable with some fault, negligence, carelessness, or want of prudence, the plaintiff … is not entitled to recover.”

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: A person who owns or controls an animal has a duty to exercise reasonable care in restraining and handling the animal so as to prevent foreseeable harm to others. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 518; see also Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (discussing foreseeability and proximate cause); Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (1982) (discussing owner responsibility for animals and foreseeability).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf does not address duties of owners or controllers of animals, nor standards for restraining or handling animals. The case is cited only for its general discussion of foreseeability, relational duty, and proximate cause, not for any animal-related duty. Using Palsgraf as authority for a specific duty of animal owners under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 518 stretches the opinion beyond its subject matter and holding.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… These cases aside, wrong is defined in terms of the natural or probable, at least when unintentional… If the harm was not willful, he must show that the act as to him had possibilities of danger so many and apparent as to entitle him to be protected against the doing of it though the harm was unintended.”

Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (.raw_text: Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (1982)
Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (.proposition: A person who owns or controls an animal has a duty to exercise reasonable care in restraining and handling the animal so as to prevent foreseeable harm to others. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 518; see also Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (discussing foreseeability and proximate cause); Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (1982) (discussing owner responsibility for animals and foreseeability).
Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (.case_name: Milton Commons Assoc. v. BD. OF APP. OF MILTON
Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns zoning procedure and the timing and effect of constructive grants of comprehensive permits under Massachusetts’ Anti-snob Zoning Act. It does not discuss animals, animal owners, duties to restrain or handle animals, or foreseeability in that context. Citing this case for a Restatement (Second) of Torts § 518-style duty of animal owners is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding of the decision.
Hayes v. Decker, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 119 (.relevant_excerpt: The case contains no discussion of animals, animal ownership, or tort duties related to animals. Its focus is on when a public hearing ends, when a constructive comprehensive permit issues under G. L. c. 40B, § 21, and how to calculate the period for judicial review of such constructive permits.

M.G.L. c. 140 (Massachusetts statutes go.raw_text: M.G.L. c. 140 (Massachusetts statutes governing dogs and livestock, including provisions concerning dogs at large and owner responsibility)
M.G.L. c. 140 (Massachusetts statutes go.proposition: Owners and keepers of animals also may be held liable for injuries caused by their failure to keep a dog under control in places where the risk of harm is foreseeable, particularly where statutory or regulatory requirements (such as leash laws or posted leash requirements) exist. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 509 (liability for conduct that creates unreasonable risk); M.G.L. c. 140 (Massachusetts statutes governing dogs and livestock, including provisions concerning dogs at large and owner responsibility).

Cook v. Austin, 389 Mass. 969 (1983).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that a landowner or other person whose conduct creates an unreasonable risk of harm to persons using a public area owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent injury. See, e.g., Cook v. Austin, 389 Mass. 969 (1983) (discussing duty and breach principles); Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (1982) (on foreseeability and duty); Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 400 Mass. 82 (1987) (proximate cause and foreseeability). (See also Restatement (Second) of Torts § 314A re: duty to invitees and licensees.)

Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (19.raw_text: Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (1982)
Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that a landowner or other person whose conduct creates an unreasonable risk of harm to persons using a public area owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent injury. See, e.g., Cook v. Austin, 389 Mass. 969 (1983) (discussing duty and breach principles); Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (1982) (on foreseeability and duty); Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 400 Mass. 82 (1987) (proximate cause and foreseeability). (See also Restatement (Second) of Torts § 314A re: duty to invitees and licensees.)
Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (19.support_reasoning: This opinion does not deal with landowner liability, unreasonable risk of harm in public areas, or tort duties at all. It concerns a reporter’s claimed constitutional and common-law privilege and the propriety of a summary criminal contempt finding. There is no discussion of foreseeability or duty in the negligence sense, so citing this case for a landowner’s duty regarding risks to persons using a public area is inaccurate.
Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (19.relevant_excerpt: Testimonial privileges are exceptions to the general duty imposed on all people to testify. Matter of Roche, 381 Mass. 624, 632-633 (1980). United States v. Bryan, 339 U.S. 323, 331 (1950). 8 J. Wigmore, Evidence § 2192 (McNaughton rev. 1961). All such privileges necessarily diminish the quantum of evidence that is before the court. P.J. Liacos, Massachusetts Evidence 174 (5th ed. 1981). Thus, privileges are generally strictly confined.

Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 400 Mass. 82 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that a landowner or other person whose conduct creates an unreasonable risk of harm to persons using a public area owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent injury. See, e.g., Cook v. Austin, 389 Mass. 969 (1983) (discussing duty and breach principles); Auble v. J.S. Ahern Co., 387 Mass. 1 (1982) (on foreseeability and duty); Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 400 Mass. 82 (1987) (proximate cause and foreseeability). (See also Restatement (Second) of Torts § 314A re: duty to invitees and licensees.)
Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 400 Mass. 82 (1.support_reasoning: Foley v. Polaroid is not a landowner or premises-liability case and does not discuss a landowner’s duty to persons using a public area. Its treatment of tort issues concerns false imprisonment, defamation, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and malicious prosecution, not duty, unreasonable risk, or landowner obligations. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts recognize a landowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent injury in public areas.
Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 400 Mass. 82 (1.relevant_excerpt: Polaroid argues that it had a duty to investigate Simon's allegations and that, because of that duty, it had a right to confine Foley in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable time for investigative purposes. Proulx v. Pinkerton's Nat'l Detective Agency, 343 Mass. 390, 392-393 (1961) ('If the circumstances are such that an investigation is warranted, a person may be detained for a reasonable length of time and in a reasonable way'). Polaroid further argues, in effect, that it was entitled to a directed verdict in its favor on the false imprisonment claim because the evidence did not warrant a finding that it detained Foley unreasonably.
